subject: Re: Somehow my posts went up out of order
msgSnippet: Thanks.  That s good to know.  I ll give it a try.  I don t know much about the shell, but I was able to put a bunch of aliases in the profile which is good
messageBody:
Thanks. That's good to know. I'll give it a try. I don't know much about the shell, but
I was able to put a bunch of aliases in the profile which is good enough for now. I'm
just using a text editor and the shell to compile for now. I'm in my third java course
so things still aren't that hectic as far as managing files / projects. I've heard the IDE
that comes with the Mac osx version of java is really good so I'll probably give that a
try one of these days. Thanks again.

-Lido

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Chappell, Simon P" <simon.chappell@l...> wrote:
> Welcome to the world of CLASSPATH ... One of the less elegant aspects of Java
development.
>
> The issue that you are dealing with here is that there are two kinds of references
that you can have in a CLASSPATH. The first is a JAR file and the second is a directory.
Unfortunately, a JAR file in a directory on the CLASSPATH does not get searched (I
know, I know, it's silly, but we have to live with it). So to address your question, you
will need to include both the reference to the Junit JAR file and the directory where the
samples live. eg:
>
> CLASSPATH=$CLASSPATH:/Applications/Utilities/Java/junit3.8.1/junit.jar:/
Applications/Utilities/Java/junit3.8.1
> export CLASSPATH
>
> This will get you to the next step, but it does sound like you need to learn a little
more about the shell, (http://www.tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/ is a good programming
guide to the bash shell).
>
> Also, I strongly suggest switching to ant (http://ant.apache.org/) for your compile/
build process. It isn't perfect, but it does 99% of most everything that I need, and I
code in Java for a living. It will also help with CLASSPATH issues.
>
> Consider switching to a CLASSPATH of ".", yes that is just the current directory and
then using the <path> facilities for individual projects.
>
> Anyway, this might have been more than you wanted, but I hope that something in
the above helps.
>
> Feel free to contact me directly if you want more help, or we can continue to work
through the mailing list so that others can be helped. :-)
>
> Simon
>
> -----------------------------------------------------------------
> Simon P. Chappell simon.chappell@l...
> Java Programming Specialist www.landsend.com
> Lands' End, Inc. (608) 935-4526
>
> "Wisdom is not the prerogative of the academics." - Peter Chappell
>
> >-----Original Message-----
> >From: Lido [mailto:lido@s...]
> >Sent: Tuesday, January 20, 2004 6:48 PM
> >To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> >Subject: [junit] Somehow my posts went up out of order
> >
> >
> >So I still have this problem (the last post that went up from
> >me made it sound like all
> >was well):
> >
> >I added this line to my bash_profile (bashrc doesn't persist
> >between sessions for
> >some reason in os x):
> >
> >export
> >CLASSPATH=$CLASSPATH:/Applications/Utilities/Java/junit3.8.1/junit.jar
> >
> >Which let junit run, but gave me this error in the junit window:
> >
> >Class not found "junit.samples.AllTests"
> >
> >So I added this to my bash_profile:
> >
> >export CLASSPATH=$CLASSPATH:/Applications/Utilities/Java/junit3.8.1/
> >
> >and tried running the tests again with:
> >
> >java junit.swingui.TestRunner junit.samples.AllTests
> >
> >But it results in this message in the bottom box in the junit window:
> >
> >Failed to invoke suite():java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError:
> >junit/tests/runner/
> >BaseTestRunnerTest$MockRunner
> >
> >For whatever reason, junit works with programs I write, but I
> >would like to see the
> >installation tests run.
> >
> >
> >
> >
